page.title: 09RAUNDS MANOR BRICKWORKS-PT.2
page.content: This sectiion describes the type of items made at the works and how they were made. The clay was dug from the claypits next to the works. It was dried and put into metal moulds. These were then stacked in kilns holding 30- 40,000 bricks, and baked for three weeks. The maximum temperature in the kilns was 1200 degrees centigrade. After being fired, they were stacked onto waiting lorries or, in earlier days, trains. The works employed 12 men during the summer, but only 4 in the winter. The works made bricks, roofing tiles and land drainage pipes. From 1919 until 1927 it specialised in wirecut facing bricks, from 1928 until 1939, hand made moulding bricks and during World War 2, land drainage pipes for the Ministry of Agriculture. Hand made facing bricks were made until 1975
